<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 885, 504]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.

<pre>Which statement is correct when S is changed from open to closed?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 589, 136, 605]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 589, 528, 605]]<|/det|>
\(V\) increases because there is a p.d. across \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 615, 136, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 615, 528, 631]]<|/det|>
\(V\) decreases because there is a p.d. across \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 641, 136, 657]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 641, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
\(V\) remains the same because the decrease of p.d. across \(r\) is balanced by the increase of p.d. across \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 682, 136, 698]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 682, 833, 698]]<|/det|>
\(V\) remains the same because the sum of the p.d.s across \(r\) and \(R\) is still equal to \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 726, 118, 742]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 726, 467, 742]]<|/det|>
What is a general description of a baryon?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 755, 136, 771]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 755, 648, 771]]<|/det|>
It consists of three quarks that must all be the same flavour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 780, 136, 796]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 780, 702, 796]]<|/det|>
It consists of three quarks that do not need to be the same flavour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 805, 136, 821]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 805, 652, 821]]<|/det|>
It consists of two quarks that must both be the same flavour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 830, 136, 846]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 830, 688, 846]]<|/det|>
It consists of two quarks that do not need to be the same flavour.

<pre>38 A stationary nucleus has nucleon number \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 918, 134]]<|/det|>
<pre>The nucleus decays by emitting a proton with speed \(v\) to form a new nucleus with speed \(u\). The new nucleus and the proton move away from one another in opposite directions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 148, 480, 163]]<|/det|>
<pre>Which equation gives \(v\) in terms of \(A\) and \(u\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 173, 136, 189]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 172, 261, 195]]<|/det|>
\[
\nu=(\frac{A}{4}-1) u
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 204, 136, 220]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 204, 252, 220]]<|/det|>
\[
\nu=(A-1) u
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 230, 136, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 230, 210, 246]]<|/det|>
\[
\nu=A u
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 256, 136, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 252, 272]]<|/det|>
\[
\nu=(A+1) u
\]
